summary.seg: This Gospel lectionary, probably produced in the second half of the 11th century or first half of the 12th, belongs in general to the fuller of the two main types, giving lections for weekdays as well as Saturdays and Sundays, except in Lent. However, in this manuscript, for the last few weeks preceding Lent, weekday lections were abandoned and only those for Saturday and Sunday given. As is quite common, the standard sequences of the synaxarion (lections of the mobile calendar, beginning from Easter) and menologion (lections for the fixed calendar, beginning from September) are followed by a series of lections for various occasions and for night vigils preceding Easter.

The manuscript has suffered the loss of numerous folios. It retained a Byzantine binding with a leather cover decorated with blind tooling, but as this was in a damaged and unstable condition, it has been rebound and the former binding retained.

msItem.title: Gospel lectionary
msItem.note: After the 11th Sunday of Luke, Saturday and Sunday lections only
Defective at the end, with lacunas: ends during the pannychidas lection for Monday of Holy Week
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἐν ἀρχὴ ἦν ὁ λόγος· καὶ ὁ λόγος ἦν πρὸς τὸν Θεὸν. καὶ Θεὸς ἦν ὁ λόγος
msItem.explicit: f. 140vΕἰς τὴν παννυχίδα τῆς ἁγίας μεγάλης Δευτέρας κατὰ Ματθαῖον

support.material: Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and quality.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i-iv] + 1-26, 28-33, 36, 38-39, 41, 43-50, 52-57, 69-73, 75, 77-78, 80, 82-86, 88-120, 123-130, 132-135, 137-138, 140 + [v-viii], in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right. Folio numbers 27, 34-35, 37, 40, 42, 51, 58-68, 74, 76, 79, 81, 87, 121-122, 131, 136, 139 have been assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practices at Cambridge University Library).

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 17 quires, of which one was originally of twelve folios and the rest are quaternia. One quire has been lost between Quires 7 and 8.

list.item: Quire 312-2 ff. 17-26 The tenth and eleventh folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 48-2 ff. 28-33 The first and last folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 58-4 ff. 36-41 The first, third, six and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 78-2 ff. 52-57 The first and last folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 88-3 ff. 69-73 The first, second and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 98-3 ff. 75-82 The second, fifth and seventh folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 108-1 ff. 83-90 The fifth folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 148-2 ff. 115-120 The seventh and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 168-2 ff. 132-138 The first and sixth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 178-7 f. 140 The first and third-eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are modern leaf signatures in Latin letters and Arabic numerals, in pencil, on the first surviving folio of each quire and occasional other folios, recto, lower right.

supportDesc.condition: There is serious pest damage to ff. 1-2, growing less severe in the following folios, with one hole continuing as far as f. 10. The lower outer corner of f. 118 has been torn away. There is water staining and areas dirt, extensive to ff. 1r-4v, and drops of wax. Text and ornament on f. 1r have suffered significant abrasion, and there has been some overwriting of this. There is some cockling.

layoutDesc.layout:
Two columns of 33 lines. 213 155
Pricking survives in the lower and outer margins, but some has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 32C2. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: The text was copied in upright mixed minuscule script similar to Perlschrift, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations appear only at the end of lines, and are rare apart from the horizontal stroke for nu. Superscript word endings do not appear. Breathings are both angular and round and mute iota is absent. Nomina sacra are unaccentuated. Use of the double dot is functional only.

Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop. The middle point often takes an unusual form, resembling a comma bent in the opposite direction from the usual.
Headings have been added in Alexandrine majuscule script in red ink.

physDesc.musicNotation: The text is provided with ekphonetic notation in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the text is preceded by a pyle in red ink with blue infill (f. 1r).
The beginning and end of sections is sometimes accompanied by simple vignettes in red or red and brown ink (e.g. f. 55r).
The text begins on f. 1r with a major initial in red ink with blue infill, in the same style as the preceding headpiece, including a hand gripping the letter.
Lections begin with minor initials in red ink. Major sections sometimes begin with a more ornate initial outlined in red ink (e.g. f. 55r).

additions.p: As part of the original production of the manuscript, parts of some lection headings were written in the margin.
Notes in English, in pencil, have been added regarding lost folios, by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886) Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 , University Librarian 1867-1886

binding.p: Modern conservation binding, Cambridge University Library 2020, with red full leather covering over wooden boards.
The pieces of the former binding, of medieval eastern Mediterranean origin, have been retained, and are housed with the manuscript.

The parchment textblock was cut to the size of the boards. Multiple sewing preparations can be identified, including 7 v-notches and 6 sawn-in recesses. This is likely evidence of multiple resewing. No sewing or sewing supports remain, except a few remnants of thread in the gatherings. No endbands are present.
There is no evidence of spine lining.
Endleaves are of laid paper. Both consist of one bifolio – the elements of which are a pastedown and a flyleaf.
It is likely the board attachment was via the covering material at the spine and the endleaves tipped at the inner joint. The boards are now detached.
The boards are wooden, with grooved edges, and are shaped to a gentle cushion at the outer spine edge.

Full covering of dark brown tanned skin, with reback in dark brown tanned skin. Repairs to the board covering in dark brown tanned skin are present at the board edges and patches on the outer board face.

Four false double raised bands, formed with cord. Decoration is blind impressions only. It consists of various intersecting fillets including a boarder of two ‘thin-thick-thin’ triple fillets. Various hand tools have been used between the fillets and at intersections, these include roundels, small and large diamond shaped florals, a square shaped floral at intersections, round tool of a double-headed eagle and a smaller round zoomorphic tool. Use of a floral intaglio tool on the spine.
There are occasional remnants of leather page-marker tabs (e.g. f. 126).

physDesc.accMat: There are two loose notes by Henry Bradshaw, regarding collation and the erasure of text.

history.origin: The manuscript was probably copied in the second half of the 11th or first half of the 12th century.
history.acquisition:
Bought by the University Library from the London bookseller
Quaritch, Bernard, 1819-1899 Bernard Quaritch in 1876.

recordHist.source: Description of binding draws upon unpublished description prepared (2020) by Samuel Foley and Cecilia Diminuco, Dept of Conservation and Collection Care, Cambridge University Library.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
